Topic.Title: For those looking to get a better look at shield....

Revenue will hit the midpoint of the range to a touch higher. Just the way they play it now. Earnings for 2013 will go up 4 to 5 cents from the Tax credit reinstatement alone. Guidance.....Jeez I hope they are aggressive but I don't know. They'll meet expectations though. I wish they had announced the Project Shield for 1Q shipment. I really want one. Stock buyback...they would be foolish not to have at least nibbled $50M or so after mentioning it. The real wild card is the dividend. I hope they are following in MCHP's shoes and just nudging a little each quarter. The fund managers just love it...I call it a 50-50

Message.Title: Nvidia Earnings Discussion
Message.Msg: Let's discuss the upcoming report + guide. My thought is that they hit the midpoint (as per usual), but that they guide for the April quarter a bit better than traditional seasonality. The rationale behind this is: - Delayed Windows 8 launch/ramp likely kept people on the sidelines who will probably come in to buy - The Apple iMac supply constraints which hurt Apple's sales in its Q4 will not be there in Q1, which means Apple sells more (high margin/high ASP) Nvidia GPUs - GeForce Titan is also likely to help the top line as it will serve as a "halo" card to drive further market share gains

Message.Title: Nvidia Earnings Discussion
Message.Msg: Let's discuss the upcoming report + guide. My thought is that they hit the midpoint (as per usual), but that they guide for the April quarter a bit better than traditional seasonality. Topic.Title: Nvidia Earnings Discussion

Message.Msg: I am using AMD's earnings as the litmus test and see them showing strong in consumer based graphics division. It spending seems to have been strong as well (mostly infrastructure) so their professional segment should come inline or slightly better. Consumer products is hit or miss but a strong showing of the nexus 7 and Audis rollout (I think will show in q4) I am hoping their guidance is inline here. So overall I have them coming in slightly above mid range due to the GPu segment again. I think they'll be aggressive with their guidance but I am not sure of the impact of new product tooling and production ramp will have...this could delay blue sky's until q2/3.

Topic.Title: Intel's 22-nm tri-gate SoC, how low can you leak?

Message.Msg: "[Intel senior fellow Mark] Bohr acknowledged that SoCs had presented Intel with new challenges. “When you talk about leakage, once you get down into the below 30 pico amp range, you have to deal with multiple sources of leakage, whether it’s through the gate oxide or leakage from source to drain or leakage from the drain to the substrate,” he said, adding that it had taken a lot of “tweaking an balancing” to finally get it right. The turning point had finally been reached, he said, with the firm’s 32-nm Medfield SoC. “You’ll see some pretty impressive SoC products coming next year on the 22nm generation,” he said. In terms of how Intel’s 22-nm SoC process stacks up against the 28-nm low power or forthcoming 20-nm processes from TSMC, Bohr claimed Intel had “far surpassed” the performance and low leakage capabilities of competitors. “We have a significant lead over our competitors,” he asserted." “We know that it’s scalable to 14-nm."

Message.Msg: The older 40nm process, as it matures, becomes cheaper per die as wafers yield more good die (Nvidia pays per wafer), so I wouldn't be surprised if that contributed to the implied GM increase.

Message.Msg: If this is all you can do in your posts, you might as well stop now. Because you'll be put on ignore by anyone with at least half a brain.

Topic.Title: Is the Last Iteration of Tegra 3 AP37 28nm?

Message.Msg: ""The older 40nm process, as it matures, becomes cheaper per die as wafers yield more good die (Nvidia pays per wafer)"" I would have to disagree with you on this one: there is a limit on the improvement on yield - it certainly cann't exceed 100%. Last we heard, about a couple of quarters ago, the 40nm process for Tegra 3 already exceeded 90+% in yield. PS: I wouldn't use this argument in your next SA article. :P

Topic.Title: Is the Last Iteration of Tegra 3 AP37 28nm?

Message.Msg: You are confusing foundry wafer line yield with SoC die yield. An 80 sq mm quad-core SoC with gpu and other SoC logic elements does not yield 90%. If it did CPB might be in profit by now ;-). There are other reasons why 40nm will be cheaper in time, TSMC will charge less for each wafer as the 40nm development cost gets fully amortized and depreciated over time.

Topic.Title: Is the Last Iteration of Tegra 3 AP37 28nm?

Message.Msg: That 90% figure refers to foundry wafer line yield and not die yield. An 80 sq mm Tegra 3 SoC with about a dozen discrete logic parts will not yield 90%, if it did CPB would be profitable by now ;-). There is also another reason why 40nm will be cheaper over time, its development cost will no longer be included in the wafer price after full depreciation.

Message.Title: "Qualcomm Completely Beats Nvidia Graphics, CMO claims"
Message.Msg: "Public perceptions die hard. A reason for Qualcomm‘s chief marketing officer Anand Chandrasekher to come out with some of his own “straight facts” to dispel the myth of Nvidia‘s graphics superiority. Snapdragon S4 Pro is better, faster than the commercially shipping Tegra 3… On benchmarks published by Anantech, S4 Pro is twice as fast than the fastest Tegra processor commercially available, said Chandresseker in an exclusive interview with TechPulse 360. Nvidia just launched their Tegra 4, not sure when those will be in the market on a commercial basis, but we believe our Snapdragon 600 outperforms Nvidia’s Tegra 4. And we believe our Snapdragon 800 completely outstrips it and puts a new benchmark in place. So, we clean Tegra 4′s clock. There’s nothing in Tegra 4 that we looked at and that looks interesting. Tegra 4 frankly, looks a lot like what we already have in S4 Pro. Qualcomm hopes for more tablet wins in 2013 Yes, they [Nvidia] had the perception [of superior graphics] help them for some time, and that helped them for some tablet wins. I think that would change. The world is increasingly becoming aware that what we have in CPUs and graphics is beyond what anybody has. So usually that technical awareness happens at the OEMs and that takes a while for products to emerge… Empirically, we completely beat them on graphics performance! Hard to be more explicit than that!" Source: Forbes

Message.Title: NVIDIA scores green victory with Italian supercomputer (Intel, move over!)
Message.Msg: There must have been a few companies that were a bit put off by the announcement of the Beacon computer as the Green500 champ last November. Everyone, that is, except Intel Corp. Beacon, developed by the National Institute for Computational Sciences (NICS) at the University of Tennessee, started out as a research project to port software code to small clusters of Intel Many Integrated Core (MIC3) chips. When the group started working with the MICs, now better known as the Xeon Phi processor line, it found some compelling energy-saving possibilities. The NICS group decided to use the technology to create a small HPC cluster. On Friday Eurotech and NVIDIA announced a new HPC system, called Eurora, that the companies say beats Beacon's energy efficiency by 26% – using NVIDIA GPUs instead of Intel Xeons, of course. With Eurora pumping out 315 gigaflops per watt versus Beacon's 299 gigaflops per watt, NVIDIA executives are happy that they can now claim the most energy-efficient HPC system uses their GPUs. .... Source: hpcwireDOTcom/hpcwire/2013-02-05/gpu_wars.html?featured=top

Message.Title: Ouya Game Console - Tegra of Course
Message.Msg: The kickstarter game console Ouya is gaining a lot of good press for itself and for Nvidia. With all the mobile ARM manufacturers to choose from you would think a game console mfg. would choose the best in graphics. Apparently they did. According to the the latest press release they have opened up pre orders at Best Buy, Amazon, Gamestop, and Target. The original 68,000 backers will get their consoles in March and the first pre orders are due to ship in April/May with units hitting retail stores in June. According to the founder they already have more in pre orders than the original 68,000 to ship in March. Put it at 150K little Tegra 3 shipments already! Price is $100 with one controller and each additional controller is $50. Put's Nvidia's Project Shield in perspective and it's expected price in perpective but the lack of a 5 inch screen, rechargeble battery, Tegra 3 vs. Tegra 4, and streaming from your PC must be balanced. Not sure how Nvidia will price their unit, but it sure is good to see Tegra chips selling into a market that didn't exist a few months ago Hope Nvidia does pre-orders too. EI have even seen new touchscreen monitors with Tegra chips in them. Who knew?

Message.Title: World’s greenest supercomputer powered by Intel and Nvidia silicon
Message.Msg: zdnetDOTcom/worlds-greenest-supercomputer-powered-by-intel-and-nvidia-silicon-7000010774/ World’s greenest supercomputer powered by Intel and Nvidia silicon Summary: Supercomputers can also be green, and the new Eurora supercomputer is the greenest of them all, topping the Green-500 list for performance per watt. By Adrian Kingsley-Hughes for Hardware 2.0 | February 4, 2013 -- 16:31 GMT (08:31 PST) It’s not just PCs and tablets that are going green, even supercomputers are having their power requirements slashed. A new supercomputer based in Italy now claims to be the greenest in the world. Called Eurora, it claims to be able to crunch its way through 3,150 megaflops per watt. Compare this to the Beacon supercomputer at the National Institute for Computational Sciences and University of Tennessee, is the current leader of the Green-500 list, which only manages 2,499.44 megaflops per watt. Europa was developed by Eurotech, and is controlled by the non-profit consortium CINECA, a group made up of 57 Italian universities and institutions. The project is based on Eurotech's Aurora node hardware. The supercomputer is made up of 64 nodes, with each node consisting of a pair of Intel Xeon E5-2687W processors, two Nvidia Tesla K20 GPU accelerator cards, an Altera Stratix V FPGA, 16GB DDR3 RAM, and a 160GB solid-state drive. Eurotech claims that each node, which is about the size of a notebook, is capable of 1,700 gigaflops per second. Each of the nodes is 30 times more powerful that a regular desktop PC, yet 15 times more power efficient. Eurotech uses a unique liquid cooling systems which allows for a more compact design, packing in 256 Tesla K20 accelerators and CPUs in a single rack while delivering 350 teraflops of peak performance. A single rack would be ranked among the top 100 supercomputers in the world, according to the latest Top500 list. With only nine racks, the system would deliver over 3.1 petaflops of performance, placing it in the top 10 of the most powerful supercomputers. Over the supercomputer’s five year lifespan, Eurotech estimates that Cineca will save 2.5 million kilowatt-hours in energy, which translates into a saving of $500,000, while also eliminating over 1,500 tons of CO2.

Topic.Title: PERDICTION:$12 to $13 for 2013

Message.Msg: I'm getting these weekly updates from Yahoo that shows comments from people I have on ignore, so I'll try to make it easy to understand how I at least decide who to ignore: 1-If you are posting one of your first posts on record under a given id (which Yahoo makes it easy to check), and you can't even make the effort in a title to spell a key word correctly, you are showing little to know desire to seem credible on the most basic level. So you are put on ignore. 2-If in looking at the history of a poster's comments, the majority of those comments are either not the appropriate subject for the board, are crude, or political or all some combination of the these traits, you are put on ignore. 3- If you are clearly a paid basher or spammer. It is not worth describing ALL the examples, but one typical one includes titles that are promising one thing and then listing a site to a spam site of some kind, you are put on ignore (if it doesn't take too much of my time). 4-If you continually bait and switch with your comments and make boastful claims about what the charts say will happen today tomorrow or whenever and 'promise' this thing is doomed to crash to this set price, etc, you are put on ignore. (I actually do this for silly claims in the other direction too but that really doesn't come up nearly as much.) I think there may be a couple of other less common traits in a poster, but these are the main ones for me. So, I'm fine with posters that actually say something constructive (and critical) of the stock but that rarely happens because most of those negative posts show little thought and effort and are usually very transparent in their intentions as a paid basher. So there you go, happy trails to ya . .

Topic.Title: Ouya Game Console - Tegra of Course

Message.Msg: Jesus Ibexx...You are one arrogant ____. But with said read what I posted again 150K Tegras sold into a market that didn't exist several months before is a good thing! As to Project Shield...sure superior in all respects and will sell very well to Gamers. probably priced like like a performance GPU card...i.e. priced $200 to $300. Now putting that in perspective. According to Jon Peddie in the first half of 2012 26% of all discrete consumer GPU cards were at the performance level(GTX 650 and GTX670) and 4.7%(GTX675 to GTX690) were enthusiast level. Considering Nvidia sold around 11 million discrete GPU cards in Q3 of 2012. The potential market for the Project Shield is around 3.5M a quarter...i.e. the performance and enthusiast Gamer guys. So the bottom line...if 10% of the Nvidia Hardcore gamers bite and buy the Project Shield we are looking at sales of 350K a quarter or 1.4 million a year. This is not chump change! Say $250 times 1.4M equals $350M in annual revenue and say $100 times 1.4M or $140M in yearly additional operating income. Anything else is gravy and should not be counted on. At least not this year. JMHO

Message.Title: Nvidia: High performance ARM servers 'one or two years' away
Message.Msg: zdnetDOTcom/nvidia-high-performance-arm-servers-one-or-two-years-away-7000006513/ Nvidia: High performance ARM servers 'one or two years' away Summary: Nvidia believes that high-performance servers will remain the domain of the x86 architecture for the next few years, but that ARM processors, combined with the power of the GPU, will eventually take over. By Adrian Kingsley-Hughes for Hardware 2.0 | October 29, 2012 -- 09:43 GMT (02:43 PDT) While there's a certain allure to using ARM processors for server applications because of their low power consumption, Nvidia believes the chips won't be ready for high performance applications for a couple of years. Sumit Gupta, general manager of Nvidia's Tesla accelerated computing unit, sees the x86 architecture as being the king of the server room, for the time being at any rate. "Performance of these ARM cores is still not where it needs to be for servers. It is getting there; the new ARM64 is going to get it part of the way," said Gupta, as reported by The Inquirer. "One day I think ARM will at least get to similar performance levels as X86 performance. The belief is that over the next one or two years these ARM SoCs will be good enough for cloud applications and web serving. I think it will take some more time to be good enough for accelerated computing"

Topic.Title: Nvidia: High performance ARM servers 'one or two years' away

Message.Msg: "The belief is that over the next one or two years these ARM SoCs will be good enough for cloud applications and web serving. I think it will take some more time to be good enough for accelerated computing" So...misleading title.

Message.Title: Gentlemen - Nvidia's Gone Back to It's Roots - Gaming!
Message.Msg: Tablets sure and a lot of them, A few world class phones OK, Project Denver----maybe someday! But right now it's all all about Gaming. Not sexy stuff...just makes money and builds cash. Sell side WS ain't gonna pick up on it so no double double this year. But if Nvidia returns cash to shareholders in the form of increased dividends, and buys back some shares each quarter we should see a 30% to 40% share price increase through the year. Very boring I know....but what can I say. Oh I know: NVIDIA's GOT' GAME!
